DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Regional Lymph Node Disease Response Status
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response used to indicate the pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment observed in a malignant tumor(s) located in a regional lymph node(s).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Regional Lymph Node Disease Response
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._A lymph node that drains lymph from a region of interest._The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: A lymph node that drains lymph from a region of interest.:The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node that drains lymph from a region of interest.
The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

DataElementConcept.origin: ECOG CRF:Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A condition or state at a particular time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An evaluation of the clinical response of the disease to the therapy.

Concepts.definition: An evaluation of the clinical response of the disease to the therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer that is neither decreasing nor increasing in extent or severity.

Concepts.definition: A disease that is neither decreasing nor increasing in extent or severity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer that is neither decreasing nor increasing in extent or severity.: Remain in force or carry on without letup; keep or maintain in unaltered condition; exist in time or space without stop or interruption.: A disease that is confined to a specific organ or tissue and has not spread to other anatomic sites.

Concepts.definition: A disease that is neither decreasing nor increasing in extent or severity.
Remain in force or carry on without letup; keep or maintain in unaltered condition; exist in time or space without stop or interruption.
A disease that is confined to a specific organ or tissue and has not spread to other anatomic sites.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The worsening of a disease over time.: Add as part of something else; put in as part of a set, group, or category.: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

Concepts.definition: A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.
Add as part of something else; put in as part of a set, group, or category.
Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Complete Response determined by pathologic review.

A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site.  Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A tumor that has spread from its original (primary) site of growth to another site, close to or distant from the primary site.  Metastasis is characteristic of advanced malignancies, but in rare instances can be seen in neoplasms lacking malignant morphology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made.

Concepts.definition: Tumor cells that remain in the body following cancer treatment.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: A condition or state at a particular time.
